document_metadata.title: Information Requests to Resolve Critical Unknowns
document_metadata.scope: Prioritized data requests to resolve high-impact unknowns in revenue durability assessment

information_requested: Revenue from top 10, 20, 50, 100 customers (dollar amount and % of total) for FY2022-2024
Customer list with revenue ranking (anonymized if necessary for confidentiality)
Contract terms for top 20 customers: billing model, contract duration, renewal dates, termination provisions, early termination fees
Customer tenure distribution (how many customers 0-1 years, 1-3 years, 3-5 years, 5+ years)
Sector/vertical concentration: revenue by industry (government, healthcare, financial services, manufacturing, etc.)
Geographic concentration: revenue by region/country
Customer satisfaction scores (NPS, CSAT) for top 50 customers with trend over 2 years
unknowns_requests.why_critical: Customer concentration determines tail risk magnitude. If top 10 customers represent 25%+ of revenue, single customer loss creates material cliff (potentially $50-100M immediate revenue loss with 30-90 day notice under month-to-month billing). Government sector concentration amplifies acquisition scenario risk (foreign buyer loses ALL government revenue immediately). Cannot quantify maximum downside or stress-test scenarios without customer concentration data. BLOCKING: Prevents accurate risk-adjusted valuation—concentration creates hidden cliff risk that may be 2-5X larger than apparent from aggregate revenue trends.
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #1 (customer concentration). Enables: (1) Maximum revenue loss quantification for single-event scenarios (customer bankruptcy, competitive loss, service failure), (2) Sector concentration risk assessment (government, healthcare), (3) Renewal timing risk (if large customers co-terminate, creates lumpy cliff risk), (4) Geographic/regulatory concentration (jurisdiction-specific risk), (5) Relationship strength inference (long-tenure customers more stable). Moves tail risk assessment from UNKNOWN to QUANTIFIED.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Should be available from management—standard diligence request. Customer list may require NDA due to confidentiality. Government customer identities may be classified/restricted. Revenue concentration for top customers should be readily available from billing systems. Contract terms for top customers should be accessible from contract management system.

unknowns_requests.request_title: Churn and Retention Metrics by Segment
information_requested: Gross revenue churn rate by segment (Public Cloud, Private Cloud, Government, UK Sovereign, Email, Professional Services) monthly for FY2022-2024
Customer count churn rate by segment for same period
Net revenue retention rate by segment (includes churn, downsell, upsell, expansion)
Cohort retention curves: for customers acquired in FY2020, FY2021, FY2022, FY2023—show survival rate by months since acquisition
Churn decomposition: voluntary vs involuntary (bankruptcy, M&A), competitive displacement vs price sensitivity vs service quality
Logo churn vs revenue churn (are high-value or low-value customers churning faster?)
First-year retention rate for new customers (cohort acquired in FY2023, what % retained after 12 months?)
unknowns_requests.why_critical: Churn is PRIMARY DRIVER of revenue durability. Currently can only INFER minimum 21% gross churn from net leakage math, but actual magnitude and segment decomposition unknown. Churn determines: (1) Customer lifetime (20% churn = 5 years, 25% = 4 years, 30% = 3.3 years), (2) Treadmill speed (how much acquisition required to maintain flat revenue), (3) LTV/CAC viability (short lifetimes make acquisition uneconomical), (4) Acceleration risk (is churn stable or increasing?). BLOCKING: Cannot project revenue trajectory or assess growth viability without churn data. Cannot determine if 21% leakage is STABLE (manageable) or ACCELERATING (death spiral).
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #2 (gross churn by segment). Enables: (1) Segment-specific revenue projections (apply actual churn rates to segment revenue base), (2) Customer lifetime calculation (1/churn rate), (3) Cohort LTV analysis (combine lifetime with revenue per customer per period), (4) Churn acceleration detection (trend analysis), (5) Retention strategy assessment (which segment interventions working/failing?), (6) Adverse selection identification (if new cohorts churn faster than old, acquiring wrong customers). Moves revenue forecasting from GUESSWORK to DATA-DRIVEN.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Should be available from management—critical operational metric that subscription businesses track religiously. May be considered competitively sensitive (unwillingness to disclose high churn publicly), but standard diligence request. Cohort analysis may require effort to compile from billing system if not already tracked. Churn decomposition may be partially subjective (exit surveys, customer feedback) but directional assessment possible.

information_requested: Bookings by type: ARR (annual recurring revenue) vs TCV (total contract value multi-year) vs Professional Services (one-time project) for FY2022-2024
ARR bookings growth separately from total bookings growth
Bookings-to-revenue conversion timeline analysis: for bookings in Q1 2023, what % converted to revenue by Q2 2023, Q3 2023, Q4 2023, Q1 2024, etc.?
Professional services bookings separately disclosed with conversion rate to managed services ARR (land-and-expand effectiveness)
Bookings cancellation/pushout rate (bookings signed but not implemented, or customers cancel before go-live)
Pipeline coverage ratio: bookings pipeline (weighted by stage/probability) vs quota for next 4 quarters
Sales efficiency: New ARR / Sales & Marketing expense (CAC payback proxy)
unknowns_requests.why_critical: 14% bookings growth is ONLY positive metric in otherwise declining business. But 21% net leakage proves bookings NOT converting to revenue growth. Must understand: (1) Is bookings definition inflated? (TCV counted upfront creates false growth vs annual revenue recognition), (2) Is conversion failing? (implementation delays, customer cancellations, professional services not converting to ARR), (3) Is bookings quality poor? (acquiring low-LTV customers). BLOCKING: Cannot assess whether pipeline health real or illusory. If bookings growth is TCV inflation or professional services (non-recurring), then NO recurring revenue growth engine exists—business in terminal decline masked by misleading metric.
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #3 (bookings composition) and #7 (professional services conversion). Enables: (1) True demand assessment (is ARR bookings growing or declining?), (2) Conversion health (are bookings becoming revenue efficiently?), (3) Growth engine viability (is professional services land-and-expand working?), (4) Forecast accuracy (apply actual conversion curves to bookings to project future revenue), (5) Sales effectiveness measurement (ARR per sales dollar). Determines whether 14% bookings growth is REAL pipeline or MEASUREMENT ARTIFACT.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Should be available from management—SaaS/subscription companies routinely track ARR bookings separately from total bookings. Conversion analysis may require effort but critical for sales operations management. Professional services conversion tracked for land-and-expand effectiveness measurement. Pipeline data standard for sales forecasting. Some metrics may be considered sensitive but are standard diligence requests.

unknowns_requests.request_title: Government Segment Financial Detail and Acquisition Impact Analysis
information_requested: Rackspace Government Solutions entity standalone financials: revenue, gross profit, operating income, EBITDA for FY2022-2024
Government customer count, revenue per customer, top 5 agency concentration
Government contract expiration schedule: revenue up for renewal by quarter for next 8 quarters
FedRAMP authorization details: scope, any limitations, re-authorization requirements, historical review outcomes
Acquisition scenario analysis: (1) Foreign buyer—revenue loss timeline and magnitude, (2) Domestic buyer—disruption assessment, customer retention risk, re-authorization requirements and timeline
Government customer satisfaction and retention rates vs commercial segments
Personnel requirements: US citizen count, clearance levels, geographic restrictions
unknowns_requests.why_critical: Government revenue estimated $270-410M (10-15% of total, 25-35% margin = $70-145M OI) but actual unknown. Foreign acquisition creates IMMEDIATE REVENUE LOSS (FedRAMP invalidation). Domestic acquisition creates TRANSITION RISK (customer uncertainty, re-authorization potential). BLOCKING: Cannot assess acquisition scenario viability without government segment quantification. Foreign buyers must haircut government revenue to ZERO in valuation. Domestic buyers must assess disruption risk. Government revenue invisibility creates VALUATION UNCERTAINTY of $300-600M (applying 2-3X revenue multiple to $200-400M segment).
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #10 (government revenue magnitude and concentration). Enables: (1) Acquisition scenario modeling (foreign buyer loss quantification, domestic buyer transition risk), (2) Buyer pool segmentation (foreign buyers excluded from valuation, domestic buyers adjust for risk), (3) Revenue stability assessment (contract renewal schedule shows cliff risk timing), (4) Regulatory compliance risk (FedRAMP scope and limitations). Moves acquisition analysis from SCENARIO SPECULATION to QUANTIFIED IMPACT.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Government Solutions entity-level financials should exist (separate legal entity requires standalone accounting). May be considered sensitive due to government customer confidentiality and competitive intelligence. Customer identities may be classified. Contract details may have NDA restrictions. But revenue, margin, customer count aggregate should be available to serious buyer. FedRAMP details public record (authorization scope published). Acquisition impact analysis may require legal/regulatory assessment.

unknowns_requests.request_title: VMware Cost Impact and Customer Pass-Through Decision Analysis
information_requested: VMware licensing costs: FY2022, FY2023, FY2024, FY2025 budget (showing Broadcom price shock impact)
VMware cost allocation: $ per Private Cloud customer or per infrastructure unit (host, CPU, storage TB)
Customer pricing decisions: Have prices been increased to pass through VMware costs? If yes, which customers, what magnitude, timing, customer response?
Private Cloud margin decomposition: 38.6% gross margin—what portion is VMware license cost? What would margin be if VMware costs absorbed vs passed through?
Customer pricing elasticity analysis: If Private Cloud prices increased 20-40%, what churn expected based on switching cost economics and customer feedback?
Alternative platform migration plan: Is Rackspace migrating customers off VMware to OpenStack, Microsoft Hyper-V, or other platforms? Timeline, cost, customer loss risk?
Broadcom relationship: Any negotiation leverage, volume discounts, program participation that could mitigate price increases?
unknowns_requests.why_critical: VMware cost shock estimated $100-210M annual increase creates IMPOSSIBLE CHOICE: absorb (margin collapse) or pass through (churn acceleration). Private Cloud contributes 40-50% of operating income—margin compression or revenue loss creates existential profitability threat. BLOCKING: Cannot project Private Cloud financial trajectory without knowing: (1) Actual VMware cost impact (is $100-210M estimate accurate?), (2) Pass-through decision (absorb vs customer pricing), (3) Customer response (tolerate or churn?). If pass-through already occurred in FY2024 and 13% decline is RESULT, then churn acceleration already materializing. If pass-through PENDING, then decline accelerates in FY2025-2026.
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #5 (VMware pass-through decision and impact). Enables: (1) Private Cloud margin projection (apply cost shock to margin decomposition), (2) Revenue churn modeling (apply elasticity to price increase scenarios), (3) Profitability trajectory (margin compression OR revenue loss quantification), (4) Strategic option assessment (stay on VMware vs migrate, economics of each path). Determines whether Private Cloud in GRADUAL decline or ACCELERATING collapse.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: VMware costs should be available from vendor agreements and accounting records. Cost allocation may require effort but necessary for customer pricing analysis. Customer pricing decisions internal management decision—should have documentation of analysis, decision, implementation. Margin decomposition should exist from cost accounting. Elasticity analysis may be subjective (customer feedback, competitive intel) but directional. Platform migration feasibility likely assessed internally given VMware crisis.

unknowns_requests.request_title: Email Hosting Segment Performance and Post-Price-Increase Results
information_requested: Email hosting revenue: FY2022, FY2023, FY2024, Q1 2026 (post-price-increase)
Email customer count and mailbox count trends (showing churn from price increase)
Email segment operating margin (profitability before and after price increase)
Partner channel reaction: How many partners exited? What % of email customers were partner-sourced?
Customer churn by customer size: Did SMB (<50 mailboxes) churn more than mid-market (50-500 mailboxes)?
Email cost structure: Fixed platform costs that create death spiral if customer base shrinks below threshold
Strategic plan: Exit segment, harvest segment, or attempt to stabilize?
unknowns_requests.why_critical: Email hosting is DEFINITIVE TEST CASE proving revenue retention is inertia-based not loyalty-based. 706% price increase triggered immediate churn. NEED QUANTIFICATION: What % of revenue/customers lost? This calibrates churn elasticity for other segments—if email lost 60% of customers from 706% increase, what would 20-40% Private Cloud increase (VMware pass-through) cause? Email also material revenue ($135-275M estimated)—if churn 60-70%, loses $80-180M revenue (3-7% of total). Post-price-increase results (Q1 2026) not yet available at analysis date February 2026, but should be known by April 2026 Q1 earnings. REPUTATIONAL IMPACT also needs assessment—enterprise customer concern about pricing behavior.
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #4 (email revenue and churn magnitude). Enables: (1) Churn elasticity calibration (price sensitivity benchmark for other segments), (2) Revenue trajectory adjustment (email death spiral impact on FY2026 forward), (3) Reputational risk assessment (brand damage quantification), (4) Pattern generalization (if email proves zero loyalty, validates hypothesis for other low-lock-in segments). Email is NATURAL EXPERIMENT—analyzing results provides insight into underlying revenue fragility across portfolio.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Email revenue should be tracked internally even if not disclosed publicly. Post-price-increase results will be available in Q1 2026 earnings (April 2026 estimated) or earlier from internal monthly/weekly tracking. Customer count and mailbox count from billing systems. Partner channel feedback from partner communications. Cost structure from accounting. Strategic plan from management discussion. Most data should become available within 60-90 days (Q1 2026 close).

unknowns_requests.request_title: Customer Acquisition Economics and LTV/CAC Analysis
information_requested: Sales and marketing expense allocated to: (1) New customer acquisition, (2) Existing customer upsell/expansion, (3) Customer retention/success
CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost) by segment: Public Cloud, Private Cloud, Government calculated as allocated S&M expense / new customers acquired
Cohort LTV analysis: For customers acquired in FY2020, FY2021, FY2022—what is realized lifetime value to date? Projected LTV at maturity?
CAC payback period by segment: Months of customer revenue required to recover acquisition cost
LTV/CAC ratio by segment and trend over time (improving or deteriorating?)
New customer first-year profitability: Are new customers profitable in Year 1 or requiring multi-year payback?
Acquisition channel economics: Direct sales vs partners vs digital/self-service—CAC and LTV by channel
unknowns_requests.why_critical: With 21% gross churn, must acquire $574M+ annually just to decline 7%. If acquisition is UNPROFITABLE (CAC exceeds LTV), then spending hundreds of millions DESTROYING value to slow revenue decline. Stage 4 identified sales booking unprofitable deals—suggests adverse selection (low-quality customer acquisition). Need to quantify: Are new customers profitable lifetime investments or value destruction? With estimated 4-5 year customer lifetime (from 20-25% churn), CAC payback MUST be <24 months for positive LTV/CAC. If payback longer, acquisition uneconomical. BLOCKING: Cannot assess whether growth POSSIBLE (can acquire profitably) or business in TERMINAL DECLINE (can only grow unprofitably).
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #8 (CAC and payback period). Enables: (1) Growth viability assessment (can company grow profitably or only unprofitably?), (2) Capital allocation optimization (which segments/channels have positive LTV/CAC?), (3) Sales strategy assessment (are current acquisition efforts economically rational?), (4) Treadmill sustainability (can company afford to replace 21% churn indefinitely?). Determines whether business CAN be turned around (acquire profitably and fix retention) or is TERMINAL (acquisition uneconomical, retention unfixable).
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: S&M expense allocation may require effort if not currently tracked by function. CAC calculation requires combining S&M allocation with new customer acquisition counts—should be possible from sales data. LTV calculation requires cohort revenue tracking—should be available from billing system but may require analytical effort. Payback period calculation straightforward once CAC and customer revenue known. LTV/CAC ratio standard SaaS metric that growth-focused companies track. May be considered sensitive but standard diligence request.

unknowns_requests.request_title: UK Sovereign Segment Development and Trajectory Assessment
information_requested: UK Sovereign revenue by month since March 2024 launch (11 months of data)
UK Sovereign customer count: total, by type (government vs commercial), by status (pilot vs production)
UK Sovereign pipeline: identified prospects, qualified opportunities, weighted forecast
BT partnership economics: revenue share, exclusivity terms, partnership obligations/restrictions
UK Sovereign competitive landscape: AWS UK Sovereign Cloud status, other UK-only providers, market share estimates
Customer satisfaction: NPS, CSAT for UK Sovereign customers vs global customer base
Investment to date and planned: CapEx, OpEx, personnel dedicated to UK Sovereign through maturity
Breakeven analysis: At what revenue level does UK Sovereign become profitable? Timeline to reach?
unknowns_requests.why_critical: UK Sovereign is ONLY GROWTH INITIATIVE but high execution risk and competitive threat. Segment immaturity (10 months old) means trajectory unclear. If segment succeeds (reaches $100-150M with 30-40% margin), contributes $30-60M OI and validates international compliance-moat model. If segment fails, $5-15M investment becomes sunk cost with zero recovery (architecturally isolated infrastructure cannot be repurposed). NEED TRAJECTORY ASSESSMENT: Is segment on-track (customer acquisition accelerating, pipeline growing), at-risk (customer acquisition stalled, pipeline weak), or failing (pilot-to-production conversion failing, AWS competitive threat materializing)? Success probability estimate currently 30-50%—data would refine to more precise assessment.
unknowns_requests.how_resolves_uncertainty: Eliminates UNKNOWN #6 (UK Sovereign trajectory and viability). Enables: (1) Growth narrative credibility assessment (is UK Sovereign real growth engine or struggling?), (2) Investment return projection (will segment generate positive ROI or become write-off?), (3) Competitive threat timing (AWS UK Sovereign launch date and impact assessment), (4) Strategic option analysis (double down on UK Sovereign, maintain current course, or exit before sunk costs escalate). Determines whether UK Sovereign is STRATEGIC ASSET or LIABILITY.
unknowns_requests.expected_availability: Revenue and customer count should be tracked internally for new segment—management dashboarding. Pipeline data standard for sales forecasting. BT partnership terms in contract but may have confidentiality restrictions. Competitive intelligence may require market research. Customer satisfaction should be tracked. Investment and breakeven analysis should exist from business case approval. Segment immature means some metrics unstable, but directional assessment possible. May become public disclosure in FY2025 if segment reaches materiality (>5% revenue) or highlighted strategically.

request_prioritization_rationale.critical_tier_logic: CRITICAL requests (RQ-5.1-001 through RQ-5.1-005) address BLOCKING unknowns that prevent accurate valuation or scenario analysis. Customer concentration determines tail risk magnitude. Churn determines revenue trajectory sustainability. Bookings composition determines whether growth engine exists. Government segment determines acquisition scenario viability. VMware impact determines Private Cloud trajectory. Without these, cannot perform risk-adjusted valuation—uncertainty range too wide (could be 50-100% valuation variance).
request_prioritization_rationale.high_tier_logic: HIGH requests (RQ-5.1-006 through RQ-5.1-007) address MATERIAL unknowns affecting profitability assessment and growth viability. Email results provide churn elasticity calibration. CAC/LTV determines whether profitable growth possible. Without these, cannot assess whether business TURNABLE (fixable issues) or TERMINAL (structural decline). Significant valuation impact but not blocking.
request_prioritization_rationale.medium_low_tier_logic: MEDIUM-LOW requests (RQ-5.1-008) address STRATEGIC unknowns about growth initiatives. UK Sovereign important for narrative but immaterial near-term (small revenue base, high uncertainty). Would refine growth story credibility but not change core valuation significantly. Can proceed with conservative assumption (low success probability) without data.

expected_data_room_coverage: Standard M&A diligence data room should include: customer list with revenue (RQ-001), financial metrics by segment (RQ-002 churn, RQ-004 government), bookings analysis (RQ-003), major vendor agreements (RQ-005 VMware). Email results (RQ-006) may not be in data room if event too recent—requires management update. CAC/LTV analysis (RQ-007) often NOT in standard data room—requires custom analysis. UK Sovereign (RQ-008) may be incomplete due to segment immaturity. RECOMMENDATION: Submit CRITICAL tier requests immediately upon data room access, prioritize these in management presentations. HIGH tier requests should be included in diligence question list. MEDIUM-LOW tier can be deferred to follow-up if time constrained.
